skill.name: meeting-notes
skill.description: Convert meeting discussions into clear, actionable notes with tasks, decisions, and follow-ups fo...
skill.summary: Convert meeting discussions into clear, actionable notes with tasks, decisions, and follow-ups fo...
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only AI instructions for formatting meeting notes. No executable code, file access, network calls, or command execution. All static findings are FALSE POSITIVES - the scanner triggered on meeting note TEMPLATE content, not actual security vulnerabilities. References to security concepts (JWT, rate limiting) are discussion topics within example meeting notes, not implementations.

content.user_title: Create structured meeting notes with action items
content.value_statement: Meeting notes often become disorganized and miss key action items. This skill provides templates and structured approaches to capture decisions, tasks, and follow-ups in formats that teams can easily reference and track.
actual_capabilities: Capture key discussion points, decisions made, action items assigned, questions raised, parking lot items, and follow-up needs from meeting discussions
Structure notes with clear formatting including headings, bullet points, tables, and searchable content in chronological flow
Extract action items with specific owners, clear deadlines, acceptance criteria, dependencies, and priority levels
Highlight decisions with what was decided, why, who decided, impact implications, and next steps
Provide templates for standard meetings, standups, sprint planning, retrospectives, and decision logs
Enable follow-through by organizing notes for prompt sharing, tracking in project management tools, scheduling follow-ups, and archiving for future reference
limitations: Cannot determine meeting context or attendee information without human input
Cannot distinguish truly important points from minor tangents without human judgment
Cannot generate specific deadlines or estimate effort without human input
Requires accurate and complete meeting discussion to produce useful notes

use_cases.title: Standard Team Meetings
use_cases.description: Document regular team meetings with agenda, discussion summaries, decisions made, and action items with owners and due dates for effective team alignment and accountability.

use_cases.title: Sprint Planning Sessions
use_cases.description: Capture sprint goals, capacity planning, backlog items with estimates and dependencies, commitment stories, and risks for agile team planning.

use_cases.title: Sprint Retrospectives
use_cases.description: Structure what went well, what didn't go well, action items, and experiments for continuous team improvement and sprint velocity tracking.

use_cases.title: Daily Standups
use_cases.description: Quickly capture yesterday's accomplishments, today's plans, and blockers in a consistent format for async team communication.

use_cases.title: Decision Logging
use_cases.description: Document key decisions with rationale, impact assessment, and owners to prevent decision re-litigation and maintain institutional knowledge.

prompt_templates.title: Standard Meeting Notes
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create structured meeting notes from this discussion:

Meeting: [Title]
Date: [Date]
Attendees: [List]

Capture:
1. Key discussion points and context
2. Decisions made with rationale
3. Action items with owner, due date, and acceptance criteria
4. Questions raised and their answers
5. Parking lot items for future discussion
6. Follow-up items and next meeting date

Format with clear headings, bullet points, and tables where helpful.
prompt_templates.scenario: General meeting documentation with full context capture

prompt_templates.title: Sprint Planning Notes
prompt_templates.prompt:
Document this sprint planning session:

Sprint: [Number]
Duration: [Dates]
Team: [Team name]

Structure:
- Sprint goal and success metrics
- Capacity planning with availability
- Backlog items with estimates, owners, and dependencies
- Sprint commitment table
- Risks and mitigations
- Action items for sprint preparation

prompt_templates.title: Retrospective Notes
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create retrospective notes:

Sprint: [Number]
Date: [Date]

Structure:
- Sprint overview with metrics
- What went well (with examples)
- What didn't go well (with impact)
- Action items with owners and due dates
- Experiments to try
- Team appreciations

prompt_templates.title: Decision Log Entry
prompt_templates.prompt:
Document this decision:

Decision: [What was decided]

Include:
- Rationale (why this decision)
- Impact and implications
- Who made the decision
- Timeline and milestones
- Related decisions or dependencies
- Action items resulting from decision
prompt_templates.scenario: Recording key architectural or process decisions

output_examples.input: Team meeting discussion: We decided to prioritize security fixes over new features this sprint. Bob will fix the JWT vulnerability by Friday. Carol will work on bundle size reduction. Alice will share the security report with the team today. We agreed to implement performance budgets in CI. Next meeting in two weeks to check progress.
output_examples.output:
# Team Meeting Notes

**Date**: [Today's Date]
**Attendees**: Alice, Bob, Carol

## Decisions Made

### Security Priority Decision
- **Decision**: Prioritize critical and high-severity security issues, delaying feature work if necessary
- **Rationale**: Security risks outweigh feature velocity; customer trust is paramount
- **Impact**: Sprint scope reduced by 20%; feature "Advanced Filtering" moved to next sprint

## Action Items

| Item | Owner | Due | Priority |
|------|-------|-----|----------|
| Fix JWT vulnerability | Bob | Friday | P1 |
| Bundle size reduction plan | Carol | TBD | P2 |
| Share security report | Alice | Today | P1 |

## Follow-Up
- Next meeting: 2 weeks for progress check

output_examples.input: Sprint retrospective: The payment integration went well thanks to early security involvement and good collaboration. PR reviews improved from 18 to 8 hours average. But we had scope creep mid-sprint that pushed us to 120% capacity. We need a scope freeze policy. The cart bug that escaped testing was due to untested discount plus tax interaction.
output_examples.output:
# Sprint Retrospective

**Sprint**: [Number]
**Date**: [Date]

## What Went Well ‚úÖ

- **Payment Integration Success**: Launched on time due to early security involvement, thorough testing, and good backend/frontend collaboration
- **PR Review Speed**: Average time decreased from 18 hours to 8 hours with 24-hour SLA and smaller PRs

## What Didn't Go Well ‚ö†Ô∏è

- **Scope Creep**: Checkout improvements expanded from 5 to 13 points mid-sprint, causing incomplete work and team stress
  - **Root Cause**: Requirements not fully defined, didn't say "no" to additions
  - **Action**: **[Alice + David]** Define scope freeze policy by next sprint

## Production Bug Analysis
- **Issue**: Cart calculation bug with discount + tax interaction escaped to production
- **Impact**: 50 users affected, ~$500 lost revenue
- **Action**: **[Bob + Carol]** Add integration tests for cart calculations by Jan 20

best_practices: Focus on key points and decisions, not verbatim transcription - capture outcomes not discussions
Ask clarifying questions to ensure action items have owners, deadlines, and acceptance criteria
Share notes within 24 hours while details are fresh and attendees can fill in gaps
Create Jira tickets from action items with due dates, assignees, and links back to meeting notes
Use consistent naming conventions and tagging for searchability and discoverability
anti_patterns: Writing verbatim transcripts instead of capturing key points and decisions
Recording action items without owners, due dates, or acceptance criteria
Waiting more than 24 hours to share notes - context fades quickly
Including every detail instead of focusing on actionable outcomes
Failing to link related documents or previous meeting notes for context

faq.question: How do I handle meetings with multiple topics?
faq.answer: Break notes into sections by topic using clear headings. Include time allocations for each topic. Prioritize sections by importance or decision content. Add a table of contents for longer meetings with many topics.

faq.question: What if action items are unclear during the meeting?
faq.answer: Ask clarifying questions in the moment: 'Can you restate this action item with a specific owner?' 'What's the deadline?' 'What does done look like?' If you can't get clarity, note the item as 'unclear - needs follow-up' and assign it to the meeting organizer.

faq.question: How do I document sensitive discussions?
faq.answer: Use neutral, factual language without editorializing. Focus on outcomes and action items rather than debate details. For confidential topics, mark notes appropriately and share only with necessary stakeholders. Consider separate documentation for sensitive HR or personnel matters.

faq.question: How do I handle meetings with very long discussions?
faq.answer: Summarize lengthy debates concisely - capture the key arguments and outcome rather than every point made. Link to detailed documentation if it exists. Use bullet points for multiple perspectives. Note 'majority view' or 'decision made after extensive discussion' when relevant.

faq.question: How do I capture discussion points that don't lead to decisions?
faq.answer: Use a 'Parking Lot' section for items discussed but not resolved. Include context about why items were parked, who raised them, and what needs to happen before they can be addressed. This shows thorough documentation while keeping main notes action-oriented.

faq.question: How do I handle participants who talk too much or dominate?
faq.answer: Document their key points objectively. For action items, redirect: 'So to summarize, [name] will own X by date Y?' For tangents, note them in parking lot. In follow-up, share notes promptly so quieter team members can add missed points.
